castles.name: Château de Chambord
castles.shortDescription: Iconic Renaissance château and the largest in the Loire Valley
fullDescription: Surrounded by a fairy tale forest, Château de Chambord is a wonderland packed with half a millennium of French history and unique architectural details like a double-spiral staircase and design elements attributed to Leonardo da Vinci.

Welcome to the largest and most majestic château in the Loire Valley. This landmark building is an architectural triumph that remains a symbol of the French Renaissance in Europe, and throughout the world.

In the 16th century, the king delighted in inviting his circle to Château de Chambord, and with a visit, you can understand why – with more than 400 rooms, 77 staircases, 282 fireplaces, and over 200 chimneys, this luxurious venue is impressive.
There's more to be explored outside. Rent a boat to row on the château's canal, or take a walking trail to see the diverse fauna and flora in the surrounding forest.
highlights: Double helix staircase designed by Leonardo da Vinci

castles.name: Château de Chenonceau
castles.shortDescription: The 'Ladies’ Castle', built over the River Cher
highlights: Influence of powerful women throughout history
fullDescription: Step into the magical Château de Chenonceau, proudly spanning the River Cher since the 12th century. Explore the Royal Gardens, Dômes Gallery, Carriage Gallery, and the château itself.
Known as the 'Ladies' Castle', Chenonceau was shaped and preserved by a succession of powerful women throughout history.
Most of what you see today was built between 1513 and 1517 by Thomas Bohier and Catherine Briçonnet. The only remnant of the medieval château is the haunting dungeon tower.
Inside, discover an extraordinary collection of Renaissance furniture, tapestries, and paintings by European masters of the 16th to 18th centuries.
The artwork and gardens reflect the château’s unique heritage and the influential women who left their mark here.

castles.name: Château Royal d'Amboise
castles.shortDescription: Royal residence and final resting place of Leonardo da Vinci
highlights: Chapel containing Leonardo da Vinci’s tomb
Panoramic views of the Loire River
fullDescription: Once a Renaissance palace for French kings, Amboise was a favorite of King Francis I and remains a jewel of Italian-inspired architecture.
The Saint Hubert Chapel, reopened in June 2024 after major restoration, houses Leonardo da Vinci’s tomb in a dazzling setting of stone and gold.
From the château’s terraces, admire one of the Loire Valley’s most breathtaking panoramas, overlooking UNESCO World Heritage landscapes.

castles.name: Château Royal de Blois
castles.shortDescription: A blend of Gothic, Renaissance, and Classical architecture
fullDescription: If you're looking for a snapshot of French history, few monuments offer as complete an experience as the Royal Château de Blois, a true jewel of the Loire Valley.
From grand kings to peace-seeking queens, the château’s walls echo with royal stories, blending Gothic, Renaissance, and Classical architecture in one magnificent ensemble.
Walk in the footsteps of Joan of Arc and Henry IV as you explore its halls, and uncover hidden wonders such as the mysteriously named Chamber of Secrets.

castles.name: Château de Villandry
castles.shortDescription: Famous for its stunning Renaissance gardens
highlights: Peaceful interiors and history of restoration
fullDescription: The Royal Château de Blois offers a sweeping journey through French history in one magnificent monument.
Once home to kings and queens, its architecture blends Gothic, Renaissance, and Classical styles.
Walk in the footsteps of figures like Joan of Arc and Henry IV, and explore unique highlights such as the Chamber of Secrets.
